choices.B: Route-maps for VDOM SERVICES are excluded from HA configuration synchronization
choices.A: Route-maps are not configurable in VDOM SERVICES
choices.D: Route-maps from the Root VDOM configuration are available in VDOM SERVICES
choices.C: Route-maps from VDOM SERVICES are available in all other VDOMs

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
l Active Copper Bypass on any copper (RJ-45) network connections (for example, the RJ-45 connections for ports 1-
16 on FortiDDoS 400B or 600B/800B)
l Active Optical Bypass on Ports 17-20 on the FortiDDoS 1200B/2000B, which support LC-connector Multi-Mode
850nm Short Range optics only. This active optical bypass functionality is not available for the other fiber-optic
connections on the FortiDDoS 1200B/2000B (ports 1-17) or for any of the fiber-optic connections found on other Bseries models. The active optical bypass ports include internal lasers so external next-hop equipment can be
connected directly to these ports (using compatible optics).
Answer is Copper and LC. Just go read the datasheets.

questions.question_text: Which two types of interface have built-in active bypass in FortiDDoS devices? (Choose two.)

An administrator has configured a FortiGate device to authenticate SSL VPN users using digital certificates. A FortiAuthenticator is the certificate authority (CA) and the Online Certificate Status Protocol (OCSP) server.

Part of the FortiGate configuration is shown below:

//IMG//


Based on this configuration, which statement is true?

choices.B: OCSP checks will always go to the configured FortiAuthenticator.
choices.D: The OCSP check of the certificate can be combined with a certificate revocation list.
choices.A: If the OCSP response is CertStatus unknown, authentication will succeed if the certificate matches the CA.
choices.C: If the OCSP server is unreachable, authentication will succeed if the certificate matches the CA.
Enable BGP recursive routing on the HUB FortiGate
choices.A: Create a vdom link between VRF10 and VRF12
choices.B: Enable Multi-VDOM mode on the Hub FortiGate and add a VDOM to connect VRF10 and VRF12
choices.D: Configure route-maps to leak the selected routes using BGP

questions.question_text:
A Hub FortiGate is connecting multiple branch FortiGate devices separating the traffic centrally in unique VRFs. Routing information is exchanged using BGP between the Hub and the Branch FortiGate devices.

You want to efficiently enable route leaking of specific routes between the VRFs.

Which two steps are required to achieve this requirement? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Configure local out traffic to use the outgoing interface based on SD-WAN rules with a manual defined IP associated to a loopback interface and configure an SD-WAN rule from the loopback to the DNS server.
choices.C: Configure two DNS servers and use DNS servers recommended by the two internet providers.
choices.D: Configure local out traffic to use the outgoing interface based on SD-WAN rules with the interface IP and configure an SD-WAN rule to the DNS server.
choices.B: Configure an SD-WAN rule to the DNS server and use the FortiGate interface IPs in the source address.

discussion.content: I don't see this question in my exam.

Selected Answer: D
Seems to be correct

questions.question_text:
SD-WAN is configured on a FortiGate. You notice that when one of the internet links has high latency the time to resolve names using DNS from FortiGate is very high.
You must ensure that the FortiGate DNS resolution times are as low as possible with the least amount of work.
What should you configure?
